title: Knoll House Hotel that inspired Enid Blyton's Famous Five on sale for £15m
text:
13 shares 7

The favourite seaside hotel of children's author Enid Blyton which is said to have inspired her classic Famous Five adventures has gone on sale for £15 million.
Blyton, also famed for writing the Secret Seven and Noddy books, was such a fan of historic Knoll House Hotel in Studland, Dorset, that she would visit three or four times a year, often for weeks at a time.
It was while at the remote establishment, on the tip of the Isle of Purbeck that she would write stories influenced by her own exploits in the countryside that would later go on to become Famous Five novels.
Knoll House Hotel was a favourite seaside hotel of children's author Enid Blyton and it is said to have inspired her classic Famous Five adventures
Situated in four acres of gardens and woodland, 84-room hotel has spa, outdoor pool, golf course, tennis courts and direct beach access
Whispering Island in 1962's Five Have A Mystery To Solve is said to have been modelled on Brownsea Island in Poole Harbour which the hotel overlooks.
A note in the front of the book by the author reads: 'Yes, the island is real, and lies in the great harbour, still full of whispering trees'.
The first of her Famous Five books, Five On A Treasure Island, published in 1942, features a ruined castle that is based on Corfe Castle just a few miles from the hotel.
The portly local policeman at Studland at the time, PC Christopher Rone, is said to be the inspiration for Blyton's PC Plod character in Noddy.
And a balding hotel guest went on to become the character Bill Smugs in her Adventure Series of eight novels.

Blyton owned a farm in nearby Sturminster Newton and her second husband Kenneth Waters owned the Isle of Purbeck Golf Club from 1950 to 1965.
During their visits to Knoll House Hotel, an icon of the halcyon days of the British seaside holiday, they would always stay in the same room overlooking the sea and sit at the same table in the restaurant.
Over the years Knoll House Hotel has played host to a long list of greats from the worlds of film, TV, politics and the military.
Sir Winston Churchill took tea at the hotel in July 1940 when he visited Studland to inspect sea defences, and Allied spy Nancy Wake was a regular visitor.
Hollywood screen siren Vivien Leigh, author Roald Dahl, actors Michael Gambon and Brian Blessed and entrepreneur Sir Richard Branson can be counted among its many guests.
During their visits to Knoll House Hotel, Enid Blyton and her husband would always stay in the same room overlooking the sea and sit at the same table in the restaurant.
The property overlooks Brownlea Island in Poole Harbour and has gone on sale with Savills estate agents for £15 million
Knoll House Hotel started life as a summer residence for the aristocratic Bankes family in the early 1900s before being turned into a six-bedroom hotel by Chris and Poppy Smith in 1931.
It shut during the war and was used by troops preparing for the D-Day landings.
Kenneth and Pauline Ferguson bought it in 1959 and it has remained in their family ever since.
The hotel, situated in four acres of gardens and woodland, has been built up into an 84-bedroom property boasting a spa, heated outdoor pool, children's playground, tennis courts, a nine-hole pitch and putt golf course and direct access to Knoll Beach.
It is now on the market with Savills estate agents for £15 million after owners Michael and Christopher Ferguson decided to sell up.
Colin Wilkins, director of development at Savills, said: 'The Knoll House Hotel used to be part of the Bankes estate which ran all the way up to where the Sandbanks chain ferry now is.
'It was sold off back in the 1930s and it became a small country hotel which over the years has grown and grown.
'Initially it provided holiday accommodation for affluent Edwardians at a time when Bournemouth was a relatively young resort town.
The first of her Famous Five books, Five On A Treasure Island, published in 1942, features a ruined castle that is based on Corfe Castle just a few miles from the hotel

'The landscape was very different to what it is today - it was very remote and not easily accessed - so Knoll House Hotel was quite exclusive. It has played host to many a famous face but it is known for being the favourite hotel of Enid Blyton.
'She would go there for her holidays and it was where she would write from. When she used to visit she would stay in the principal bedroom each time with its stunning sea views, and she would sit at the same table in the restaurant.
'The adventures she had while staying at the hotel inspired her her Famous Five children's stories.One of them is set on Brownsea Island in Poole harbour and another features Tilly Whim Caves near Swanage.'
Wilkins added: 'The clientèle of the hotel is largely generations of families who have been visiting for years, because it makes for such a great family holiday.
'It's been a hotel ever since the 1930s, and has been in the same family for more than 50 years.
'The second and third generations of the Ferguson family are now running it but they feel that now is the right time to pass it on to someone else.
'It is very rare to find a property surrounded by protected landscapes with such a fantastic view across a bay to the Isle of Wight and just metres from a sandy beach.
'It's not dissimilar to a Caribbean resort hotel. This is an incredible opportunity to breathe new life into an iconic British hotel.'
